name: Pangolin
description:
The Philippine pangolin is endemic to the Philippines, inhabiting four islands including Palawan and Culion. It can be distinguished from the Sunda pangolin by its smaller scales and shorter head and body-to-tail length ratio. It is one of the most heavily poached and trafficked of the eight pangolin species. 

In some beliefs, according to Martin Walsh,  He records that it was believed pangolins fell to Earth from the sky, sent by the spirits of the Sangus’ ancestors. “Some Africans make the pangolin the central emblem of healing people who have been unable to bear children.”

It reminds us the pangolin serves as a symbol of hope that even the unhappiness of not being able to have children may be overcome.

Source: https://www.pangolinsg.org/pangolins/philippine-pangolin/
https://eia-international.org/blog/can-power-cultural-mythology-help-give-pangolins-ghost-chance/
